# Schedule Network Diagram

## Document Overview

**Project Name:** ADPA - Advanced Document Processing & Automation Framework  
**Project Type:** Modular Enterprise Software Development (AI-Powered Document Generation, Automation, and Integration Framework)

**Purpose:**  
This Schedule Network Diagram illustrates the logical relationships, dependencies, and sequencing of all major activities required to deliver the ADPA framework. It highlights critical path activities, lead/lag times, milestones, and decision points, supporting effective project control, resource allocation, and schedule optimization.

**Methodology:**  
The Precedence Diagramming Method (PDM) is used, supporting Finish-to-Start (FS), Start-to-Start (SS), Finish-to-Finish (FF), and Start-to-Finish (SF) logical relationships. The diagram incorporates critical path analysis, lead/lag times, and resource constraints per PMBOK 7th Edition best practices.

---

## Network Diagram Development

**Activity Identification:**  
Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) decomposition was performed for all major deliverables (AI Processing Engine, REST API, CLI, Integrations, Admin Interface, Testing, Documentation, Deployment). Activities were defined at a level suitable for accurate sequencing and resource assignment.

**Dependency Analysis:**  
Each activity’s logical relationship was assessed to determine the proper sequence (FS, SS, FF, SF), incorporating technical, regulatory, resource, and external constraints.

**Critical Path Determination:**  
Network logic was constructed in project management software, with durations estimated and the critical path identified by forward/backward pass analysis.

---

## Activity Network Structure

Below are detailed network diagrams for each project phase.  
**Legend:**  
- FS: Finish-to-Start  
- SS: Start-to-Start  
- FF: Finish-to-Finish  
- SF: Start-to-Finish  
- [M]: Milestone  
- [D]: Decision Point  

---

### Phase 1: Project Initiation & Planning

```
[1.1 Define Project Charter] --FS--> [1.2 Approve Charter] [M]
       |
       FS
       ↓
[1.3 Develop WBS] --FS--> [1.4 Identify Stakeholders] --FS--> [1.5 Kickoff Meeting] [M]
```
**Critical Activities:** 1.1, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5  
**Float Analysis:** None; all initiation activities are on the critical path.

---

### Phase 2: Core Architecture & Backend Development

```
[2.1 Design System Architecture] --FS--> [2.2 Set Up Repositories]
      |                                |
      SS                              SS
      ↓                                ↓
[2.3 Configure CI/CD] --FS--> [2.4 Develop AI Processing Engine] --FS--> [2.5 Develop REST API Server]
                                               |                                 |
                                               FF                                FS (Lag: 2d)
                                               ↓                                 ↓
[2.6 Develop CLI] --FS--> [2.7 Integration Layer] --FS--> [2.8 Internal API Review] [D]
```
**Critical Activities:** 2.1, 2.2, 2.4, 2.5, 2.7, 2.8  
**Float Analysis:**  
- 2.3 (Configure CI/CD): Small float (parallel to 2.2/2.4).  
- 2.6 (CLI): Can start after 2.4 starts (SS), minor float.

---

### Phase 3: Integration & Frontend Development

```
[3.1 Develop Admin Interface] --FS--> [3.2 Connect Frontend to API] --FS--> [3.3 Implement Confluence Integration]
      |                                 |                                 |
      FS (Lag: 1d)                      FS (Lag: 0d)                      FS 
      ↓                                 ↓                                 ↓
[3.4 Implement SharePoint Integration] --FS--> [3.5 Implement Adobe Integration] --FS--> [3.6 External Integration Testing] [D]
```
**Critical Activities:** 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 3.6  
**Float Analysis:**  
- Integrations may be developed in parallel where resources allow, but all must be tested in 3.6.

---

### Phase 4: Testing, Documentation, and Deployment

```
[4.1 Unit & Integration Testing] --FS--> [4.2 Performance Testing] --FS--> [4.3 User Acceptance Testing (UAT)] [D]
      |                                     |                              |
      SS                                    FS (Lag: 2d)                   FS
      ↓                                     ↓                              ↓
[4.4 Documentation Generation] --FS--> [4.5 Admin Training & Handover] --FS--> [4.6 Production Deployment] [M]
```
**Critical Activities:** 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.5, 4.6  
**Float Analysis:**  
- 4.4 (Documentation): Can start with testing; some float if resourced separately.

---

### Milestones & Decision Points

- **1.2 Approve Charter [M]**
- **1.5 Kickoff Meeting [M]**
- **2.8 Internal API Review [D]**
- **3.6 External Integration Testing [D]**
- **4.3 UAT Signoff [D]**
- **4.6 Production Deployment [M]**

---

## Critical Path Analysis

**Critical Path Sequence:**  
1.1 → 1.2 → 1.3 → 1.4 → 1.5 → 2.1 → 2.2 → 2.4 → 2.5 → 2.7 → 2.8 → 3.1 → 3.2 → 3.3 → 3.4 → 3.5 → 3.6 → 4.1 → 4.2 → 4.3 → 4.5 → 4.6

**Total Project Duration:**  
[Sum durations of all above activities; e.g., 22 weeks (dependent on actual durations and resource allocation)]

**Critical Activities:**  
All activities on the critical path listed above. Any delay in these will delay the project.

**Schedule Compression Opportunities:**  
- **Fast-tracking:** Overlap 2.4 (AI Processing Engine) and 2.5 (REST API) development where possible.
- **Crashing:** Allocate additional resources to integrations in Phase 3 to shorten duration.
- **Lead/Lag:** Reduce lag between 2.5 and 2.7, and 4.2 and 4.3 if possible.

---

## Dependency Management

### Mandatory Dependencies (Hard Logic)
- System architecture must be finalized before backend development (2.1 → 2.4)
- API server must be available before frontend integration (2.5 → 3.2)
- Testing cannot begin until all core modules are developed (3.6 → 4.1)
- UAT and deployment only after successful testing and documentation

### Discretionary Dependencies (Soft Logic)
- Prefer to complete all integrations before UAT for smoother acceptance
- Admin training may be scheduled post-UAT but before deployment for workflow optimization

### External Dependencies
- Confluence, SharePoint, and Adobe API access for integration phases
- Vendor tokens/credentials for AI providers (e.g., OpenAI, Google AI)
- Approval from enterprise IT/security for production deployment

---

## Resource Considerations

- **Resource-Constrained Activities:** Integration testing (3.6) and deployment (4.6) may require specialized personnel
- **Resource Leveling:** Parallelize development of integration modules where resource availability allows
- **Multi-Resource Activities:** UAT and admin training involve both technical and business staff
- **Resource Availability Windows:** Schedule around holiday periods and known resource absences

---

## Schedule Optimization

- **Fast-Tracking:** Parallelize backend and frontend development post-API readiness
- **Crashing:** Assign additional developers to critical integrations for faster completion
- **Resource Smoothing:** Stagger testing and documentation to prevent overloading QA staff
- **Alternative Sequencing:** If vendor APIs are delayed, prioritize internal modules

---

## Risk and Contingency

- **Schedule Risks:** Vendor API delays, resource unavailability, scope changes
- **Buffers:** Pad schedule between integration completion and UAT (buffer activity)
- **Contingency Activities:** Early proof-of-concept testing for external integrations
- **Risk Mitigation:** Weekly schedule reviews, rapid escalation for dependency blockers
- **Schedule Reserve:** Two-week management reserve prior to deployment

---

## Network Diagram Maintenance

- **Update Procedures:** Network diagram reviewed biweekly; updated after each major change (scope, integration plan, resource shift)
- **Change Control:** All changes logged in project management tool; subject to formal approval
- **Version Management:** Each approved network revision stored in version control (docs directory)
- **Stakeholder Communication:** All updates and impacts communicated in weekly project meetings and via Confluence

---

**Note:**  
This Schedule Network Diagram provides a comprehensive, standards-compliant foundation for managing the ADPA framework project. It should be tailored as actual durations, resource assignments, and technical realities evolve. For visual network diagrams, tools such as MS Project, Lucidchart, or Mermaid.js can supplement these text representations.
